results.title: Australians at war: 1939-1945: navy, army, airforce
results.creator_credit: Stuart Glover, John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
During the years 1956-1969 Frank Bagnall produced a series tracing the involvement of the Army, Navy and Airforce services during the Second World War. The series is comprised almost entirely of actual footage and is united by the themes of human effort and sacrifice. The individual episodes are available separately in the collection on 16mm. NAVY: illustrates the conditions of active service in the Royal Australian Navy in the war including missions such as an Island invasion with America, and defending bases in New Guinea and Northern Australia. ARMY: records the Australian soldier’s participation in the Second World War. Covers fighting in Libya, Greece, Crete, Syria and Tripoli, and the Singapore, New Guinea and Borneo campaigns. AIRFORCE: Australian airmen serve their country admirably, earning distinction in areas as widely separated as New Guinea and Europe. Victory comes at a cost however as machines and men are lost in the name of conflict. Repackaged by Film Australia in 1995.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_moP0lr2s1w
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xSlHLFAQlGg&t=13s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3A6szu1ca0Y&t=25s

results.title: Hawkins' rivers
results.creator_credit: Robert Heazlewood, TAS Television Productions and Eyelevel Production
results.brief_description: Leo McKern narrates this modern day adventure set in twentieth century Tasmania. The true story concerns Tasmanian doctor and canoeist John Hawkins, who led the fight to save the Franklin River. It was, and still is a dilemma between developing the natural resources of the land or to forgo development at the price of suffering potential economic, political and social consequences. It is an issue that commanded the rest of the nation’s attention and continues to be pertinent today.

results.title: Whereas the people
results.brief_description: Traces the development of the Australian Constitution and investigates its relevance for today as well as examining the politics behind its drafting. The continuous “battle” between State and Federal powers is illustrated by the Franklin Dam case and the process of Constitutional change through referendum is explained.

results.title: Big painter
results.brief_description: A chronological study of the production of a mural by John Firth-Smith begun in 1978 and completed in 1981. The huge painting measures 6m x 48m and hangs in the headquarters of the ANZ Bank, Melbourne.

results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.

results.title: Closer
results.material_description: interactive video, software, sensor pads and vinyl interactive pillars
results.brief_description:
A commission of the Australian Centre of the Moving Image, ‘Closer’ is an interactive dance installation created and produced by renowned contemporary dance company Chunky Move.

A constantly changing audiovisual environment with a single large projection of a solo dancer, Closer plays with the relationship between the audience and the interactive structures created by artists Gideon Obarzanek (Choreography), Peter Hennessey (Interactive and Visual Design), and Darrin Verhagin (Audio Landscape).

Closer combines real time video processing with sensor pads that respond to audience members using their bodies to modify the moves of the on-screen dancer.

The choreography is endlessly modified by the actions of the audience, and the audience’s actions are in turn shaped and defined by the installation, which calls upon them to touch, throw or press their bodies against the upholstered, torso-size sensor pads mounted on the walls in the installation space.

Closer redefines the installation space as a choreographic instrument, which is played by its audience to create new works every time. The work can also be described as an investigative tool, allowing the audience to explore, in more a more detail, the structure and topography of the movement and the body of the dancer. The work literally brings the audience closer to the work in every sense -closer to its creation, closer to the subtle details of its movement and closer to the body of its dancer.

As the audience engages with the work, they become increasingly aware of the reflective relationship they share with the dancer. Their interaction, via large physical actions or movements, is very different from the usual ‘mouse and keyboard’ interface that commonly defines multimedia installations. As they activate the large wall pads, their bodies are pushed into a kind of physicality that is especially unusual in a traditional gallery context. They literally impact on the work.

The choreography in Closer is itself based on impacts. A lone dancer bounces her body against a wall and, as the audience’s input increases, this gentle rebounding is transformed into something far more intense and extraordinary.

Closer, the audience’s experience of dance, usually felt from the passive distance of theatre seats, is active and intimate. The minute complexities of the body - the ripple and flex of skin and muscles, hair, pores and subtle expression - form part of the choreographic palette of Closer. This is micro-choreography. This is Closer.

results.title: Place urbanity
results.material_description: interactive video, software, platform, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Place-Urbanity immerses the visitor in 15 fully panoramic video recordings of Melbourne’s suburbs.
A pioneering and humorous work by new media artist Jeffrey Shaw, Place-Urbanity immerses the visitor in 15 fully panoramic video recordings of Melbourne’s suburbs. Each suburb is the district of a specific immigrant or ethnic community.
A robotic platform allows the visitor to rotate the projected image within a fully surrounding 9m diameter projection screen while they navigate through virtual space.
While exploring each of the panoramic scenes the visitor is entertained by a member of that community telling a joke. Place-Urbanity is a humorous comment on how different cultures establish their identities within the Australian socio-geographic context.
